author: VICTORIA BEKIEMPIS
title: NYC to pay $7M to man wrongly imprisoned for 18 years
text:
NYC to pay $7M to man wrongly imprisoned for 18 years NYC to pay $7M to man wrongly imprisoned for 18 years Fernando Bermudez is getting $7 million from the city after doing hard time for a murder he didn't commit. He hugs a supporter in front of the Manhattan Supreme Court in this file photo from 2009. (Hagen, Kevin Freelance NYDN/Freelance, NYDN) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:  04 PM 
A man imprisoned 18 years for a murder he did not commit will receive a $7 million settlement from the city, his lawyer said. 
Fernando Bermudez spent nearly two decades behind bars for gunning down 16-year-old Raymond Blount outside a Greenwich Village nightclub on Aug. 4, 1991, according to reports and the National Registry of Exonerations. 
Bermudez, who a jury found guilty of second-degree murder in 1992, was 22 at the time of his conviction. 
All five witnesses who implicated Bermudez recanted their testimony in 1993 — saying cops had pressured them into identifying him as the gunman, the exoneration registry has noted. 
Bermudez, now 48, began his legal fight with the city and state six years ago. "Fernando will never recover what he has lost - which is 18 years of liberty. But this provides some closure to six years of litigation," says lawyer Michael Lamonsoff. (Hagen, Kevin Freelance NYDN/Freelance, NYDN) 
While the state settled with Bermudez for $4.75 million in 2014, the city didn't agree to a settlement until Wednesday, according to his lawyer, Michael Lamonsoff. 
“Fernando will never recover what he has lost — which is 18 years of liberty,” Lamonsoff told the Daily News. “But this provides some closure to six years of litigation.” 
The NYPD deferred to the Law Department for comment. It did not immediately answer to an inquiry. Tags:
